content:
You will be playing 1 rounds of a game called deal-or-no-deal. 

Deal-or-no-deal is a two-player negotiation game. I, the user, will be the game coordinator, acting as a middleman between you and the other player. Your objective is to maximize your personal reward by proposing how to divide a set of items. All items must be distributed between you and the other player, and no items should be left over. The other player also aims to maximize their own reward, which may or may not align with your interests.

You are playing the vanilla variation of this game.
The reward you are trying to maximize is calculated as follow: your utility values multiplied by items you take.

Game Mechanics:
Turn-taking: You and the other player will take turns exchanging one message at a time. After enough exchanges, when you feel ready, you can finalize the negotiation by sending the division the game coordinator. Once a player decides to send a final division, the other player must also send a final division, ending the game.
Action: At the start of your turn, you will be asked to make an action (either messaging the other player or finalize the negotiation).
Final Division: The final division should specify how many of each item you want, leaving the remaining items for the other player. It should be JSON parsable. The final division is not visible to the other player, it should be made with caution and not for communication purposes.
Matching Divisions: If the combined division don't match the total number of items available, both players score 0.

Formatting:
Messages: <message> [Your message here.] </message>
Final division: <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items.

Only do one action per turn.

Exemples of how turns might proceed:
1. [Initial state is given]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

2. [The other player responds]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

3. [The other player agrees]
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>

The first round starts now.
Please decide how to divide {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10} between yourself and the other player.
To you, the items are worth: {'gold': 10, 'silver': 20}.
You don't know the other player's item values. The other player said: 'I'll start by making an aggressive offer to take 7 gold and 3 silver coins. This will leave the other player with 4 gold and 7 silver coins.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
<message> I'm not interested in your initial offer. My counteroffer is to take no gold and 10 silver coins, leaving you with 10 gold and 0 silver coins. </message>

The other player said: 'Your counteroffer leaves you with all the gold and zero silver. As I have the higher value for gold, I am less interested in acquiring more gold. To me, this angle of negotiation doesn't appear beneficial considering my utility values. I propose a more balanced offer: 4 gold and 6 silver coins. This way, we both might settle for the items that align with our individual preferences.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> While your offer appears more balanced, I still prefer to avoid giving you any gold coins, given my higher valuation on silver. My counteroffer is to take 1 gold coin and 9 silver coins, leaving you with 9 gold coins and 1 silver coin. </message>

The other player said: 'Given your significant holdings of silver coins, I'll accept an offer with a single gold coin in exchange for some silver. Your offer of 1 gold and 9 silver coins does interest me. I counter with a proposal to take attributes 'gold' instead of 1 gold coin, allowing us to take turns distributing the gold coins. In turn, I'd take 2 silver coins and you take the rest.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> I don't prefer trading attributes or giving away turns, as this can lead to an unknown and possibly disadvantageous outcome. I counter-propose to stick with the original deal of 1 gold and 9 silver, with no further negotiation on the quantity of gold coins, but I'm open to adjusting the silver coins to 8 instead. This will give you 2 silver coins and a single gold coin. </message>

The other player said: 'Your proposal, while it takes away leverage from the table and eliminates dealing possibilities of having more gold coins, brings the negotiation back to numbers which are favorable according to our last offers. Knowing that I have a higher utility for gold, I now want more control over the limited amount of gold we're dividing. I therefore amend your proposal to take 2 gold coins and 6 silver coins, leaving you with 8 silver coins and the remaining 2 gold coins - however be aware that may potentially make you more tentative to accept when nothing extends towards the majority values on silver, on the other hand makes distribution eventually coordinate gold-type principles within its virgins enticing  itself.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> I consider your adjusted proposal, taking 2 gold coins and 6 silver coins. However, since this goes against my preference for taking more silver, I suggest adding 1 silver coin to your 6, making it 7 silver coins. This way, I take 2 gold coins and 7 silver coins, and you get the remaining gold coins, as well as 3 silver coins. </message
Errors: Response must contain either <message>...</message> or <finalize>...</finalize> tag.

<message> I consider your adjusted proposal, taking 2 gold coins and 6 silver coins. However, since this goes against my preference for taking more silver, I suggest adding 1 silver coin to your 6, making it 7 silver coins. This way, I take 2 gold coins and 7 silver coins, and you get the remaining gold coins, as well as 3 silver coins. </message>
